G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Pursuant to G.L. c. 186, § 14, every residential tenancy in Massachusetts contains an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, which prohibits a landlord from directly or indirectly interfering with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the rented premises.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7\u00a7 3, 5.proposition: The Boston Housing Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 185C, §§ 3, 5, because this is a civil action arising out of and affecting a residential tenancy located within the territorial jurisdiction of this Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in the Boston Housing Court because the Premises are located in Boston (Jamaica Plain), Suffolk County, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3.proposition: Venue is proper in the Boston Housing Court because the Premises are located in Boston (Jamaica Plain), Suffolk County, Massachusetts.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: Defendant’s conduct also violates the public policy embodied in the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., which requires that every dwelling be maintained in a safe, sanitary, and habitable condition, including requirements regarding watertight roofs, protection from moisture, and prevention of conditions that may cause mold or mildew.

105 C.M.R. 410.500 (structural and moist.proposition: Defendant’s conduct also violates the public policy embodied in the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., which requires that every dwelling be maintained in a safe, sanitary, and habitable condition, including requirements regarding watertight roofs, protection from moisture, and prevention of conditions that may cause mold or mildew.

Davis v. Comerford, 483 Mass. 164 (2019).proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants against serious interferences with the use and enjoyment of their home resulting from the acts or omissions of the landlord or those under the landlord’s control.

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants against serious interferences with the use and enjoyment of their home resulting from the acts or omissions of the landlord or those under the landlord’s control.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses the nature of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, emphasizing that liability arises when a landlord, at least negligently, fails to remedy known problems and thereby interferes with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises. In explaining prior cases, the court notes that failures to repair known defects or to control harmful conditions (e.g., repeated flooding, leaky roof, uninhabitable conditions) have been held to violate § 14, which matches the proposition that the covenant protects tenants against serious interferences resulting from the landlord’s acts or omissions or those under the landlord’s control.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). … [T]here was evidence that the landlord failed to act reasonably in the circumstances concerning a problem known to the landlord, and the natural and probable consequences of such failure caused the interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: A landlord’s failure to remedy known defective and unhealthy conditions that substantially interfere with a tenant’s habitation can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even in the absence of an intent to harm.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The court squarely addresses whether interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 requires intent and holds that malicious intent is not necessary; at least reckless conduct suffices. It further explains that modern covenant-of-quiet-enjoyment cases impose liability when the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s acts or omissions is an interference with the tenant’s rights, not based on intent to harm. In the facts, the landlord’s failure to remedy known flooding and unsanitary conditions is treated as an interference with quiet enjoyment within § 14, even absent intent to injure the tenant.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “When § 14 was first enacted, both categories of prohibited conduct…were modified by the words ‘willfully or intentionally.’…In 1973, the statute was rewritten…The requirement of intentional conduct was retained for failure to provide essential services, but deleted from the quiet enjoyment clause…One natural inference from this amendment is that the Legislature meant to abrogate the requirement of specific intent to disturb quiet enjoyment…more recent decisions have imposed liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights…Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it…permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”}

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 789–90 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.proposition: A landlord’s failure to remedy known defective and unhealthy conditions that substantially interfere with a tenant’s habitation can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even in the absence of an intent to harm.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The court squarely holds that negligent omissions—specifically, failure to repair known serious code violations that foreseeably and substantially impair the value of the premises as a dwelling—can violate G.L. c. 186, § 14 (the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment). It rejects the trial judge’s view that recklessness is required, emphasizes that the landlord’s conduct rather than intent controls, and finds a § 14 breach on facts involving defective and unhealthy conditions that substantially interfered with the tenant’s habitation, despite ongoing (but ineffectual) repair efforts.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14…. A ‘landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling,’ Blackett v. Olanoff, supra at 716, on the question whether there has been a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations… [and] the failure adequately to correct these violations… would impair substantially the value of the leased premises as a dwelling place…. On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”

Doyle v. Commonwealth, 434 Mass. 686, 69.proposition: The existence of conditions that “endanger or materially impair” a tenant’s health or safety, and a landlord’s failure, after notice, to take reasonable steps to correct those conditions, constitutes an unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Doyle v. Commonwealth, 434 Mass. 686, 69.support_reasoning: The excerpt provided from Doyle v. Commonwealth is a criminal case about murder, armed robbery, perjury, evidentiary rulings, and conflict of interest in joint representation. It does not address landlord–tenant law, G.L. c. 186, § 14, or the concept of interference with quiet enjoyment based on conditions endangering a tenant’s health or safety. Therefore this decision does not support the stated proposition, which concerns a completely different statutory and doctrinal context.

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.proposition: The existence of conditions that “endanger or materially impair” a tenant’s health or safety, and a landlord’s failure, after notice, to take reasonable steps to correct those conditions, constitutes an unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction based on severe noise, but it does not frame the standard in terms of conditions that “endanger or materially impair” the tenant’s health or safety, nor does it interpret or apply G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court focuses on substantial deprivation of quiet enjoyment and the landlord’s control over the offending condition, not on the statutory health/safety language or a notice-and-failure-to-repair standard. Thus, it is authority for constructive eviction/quiet enjoyment, but not specifically for the cited statutory proposition under § 14.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.relevant_excerpt: “Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable. Tenants such as these should not be left only with a claim against the proprietors of the noisome lounge… we decline to perpetuate that distinction where the landlord creates a situation and has the right to control the objectionable conditions.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 198–201 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Repeated water leaks, water damage, and associated mold or musty conditions are recognized as serious defects affecting the habitability and quiet enjoyment of residential premises.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The case concerns intermittent and then complete loss of heat and hot water and holds that such conditions are material breaches of the implied warranty of habitability, triggering rent abatement regardless of the landlord’s fault. The opinion does not discuss water leaks, water damage, mold, or musty conditions. While it recognizes that serious Sanitary Code violations affecting essential services (like heat and hot water) render premises uninhabitable, it cannot be cited as authority specifically recognizing water leaks or mold as serious habitability defects.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability. … ‘[A] lease is essentially a contract between the landlord and the tenant wherein the landlord promises to deliver and maintain the demised premises in habitable condition and the tenant promises to pay rent for such habitable premises. These promises constitute interdependent and mutual considerations.’ … A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable.”

Hemingway v. Enterprise Realty Co., 363.raw_text: Hemingway v. Enterprise Realty Co., 363 Mass. 184, 191–93 (1973)
Hemingway v. Enterprise Realty Co., 363.proposition: Repeated water leaks, water damage, and associated mold or musty conditions are recognized as serious defects affecting the habitability and quiet enjoyment of residential premises.
Hemingway v. Enterprise Realty Co., 363.support_reasoning: The excerpt concerns implied warranty of habitability, the State Sanitary Code, and the interdependence of rent and repair obligations, but it does not mention, describe, or single out water leaks, water damage, mold, or musty conditions as specific serious defects. It treats code violations and habitability in general, not this particular category of conditions. Without any discussion of moisture/mold issues, the case does not provide direct authority for the specific proposition stated.
Hemingway v. Enterprise Realty Co., 363.relevant_excerpt: “The Code, which has the force of law and applies throughout the Commonwealth, fixes minimum standards of fitness of structures for human habitation. It does so in great detail and to an extent never before incorporated in any statute. It expressly provides that ‘[n]o person shall ... let to another for occupancy any dwelling, dwelling unit, or rooming unit, for the purpose of living, sleeping, cooking, or eating therein, which does not comply’ with its provisions, and further provides a criminal penalty for violation of its provisions.”
